Is this actually valid way from keystonemiddleware perspective ?

I think the proper direction here would be to add an independent class like magnum::auth or magnum::keystone_auth and then manage paramer for the keystone_auth section, but please correct me if I missed any individual implementation in Magnum.

resolutions/20200831-reinstate-weekly-me.message: This doesn't need a meeting. It needs organisational structure, and expectations management.

I don't think we can enforce a structure and manage expectations in a fully volunteered environment.  I do think that signals like "did not attend the past 10 weekly meetings" is a one we could start using.
should remove 'are' here.
The TC has regular meetings, its frequency being once per month.
once every month is not enough

I am not sure to understand this as a current challenge: Did we recently have meeting that didn't meet quorums? Is that a one-off (holidays?), or do we have to regularily cancel tc official meetings due to quorum not being met? (AFAIK, it's not the case). Maybe I am just misunderstanding this sentence.
no, changes are not getting enough votes so they take a long time, TC-level efforts are taking a long time because we can't follow up on them, we cant just keep slowing down and become irrelevant.
I agree that a live debate is probably better than some email thread sometimes. But do we have this here?
yes, the current level of engagement on emails sent to the ML is just not working.  It took 2 weeks to come up with 2 timeslots for an office hour.

I don't disagree. But personally, I am reachable for the community anytime: Just ping me on the channel, and we can set up a meeting that suits a good time for participants (depends on the case, it's not a general rule).

100% agree. This is great to sync and talk. I am just wondering if we shouldn't have a mixed model: keeping the office hours to give progress, make it more visible, get the TC members attendance, and if necessary have extra meetings for official records.
we can keep both.  we just need a time where tc members need to absolutely block off their time and be there or be held accountable for not being there.
That's indeed a very good point, but that's also sad to say that the ML have not worked, and TC members don't follow the work by themselves, which is what you are effectively saying here.
we get busy, it happens, we need to all keep in sync
Do you mean office hour time is not a known time? It's listed on eavesdrop.
no, but i mean that generally a meeting slot will make sense for those who are interested in the on-going events of the TC

I totally agree with that statement.
They serve a different purpose.
Reinstating

So meetings once a week are better than emails on the ML?

Not sure I agree with that phrasing.
i don't think i'm saying it's better than ML, i'm just saying its good™

If they are not active at the office hours, why do you expect them to be active in a more "official" meeting?
I have the impression it's the opposite: The fact it's official might intimidate more.

because office hours are this loose things which aren't specifically defined with no agenda, it's hard to "ask for time" by randomly waltzing into an "office hour" vs adding it to a structured agenda.

Could you clarify why?

I have the impression that people are open anyway? I would expect something more informal and not logged would have more open communications instead.
do you want me to drop this?
Does it?

yes, because we take roll call, and if we stop gathering quorum, then we have to revisit and point out those who have missed X meetings in a row (or in a period of time) and figure out accountability then.
Note: While I agree, the TC and the projects don't have the same kind of deadlines. What works for a project doesn't necessary work for another, or the TC.
it's just a system, we're a team just like any other team.

That's nice to hear! I like the idea of bringing more visibility to our IRC time.

I think that might be the problem to fix with the current office hours, which were not active enough IMO.

Do you mean by this sentence that moving the office hours to a meeting would positively change the attendance and participation of non-TC members, just because it's recorded (and declared as official "meeting")?
we don't take roll call in office hours, we don't have any structure there.  see points above

build-tools/helm-chart-modify.py.message: Need to match with its name. Same as the following.

Use ruamel yaml instead.
import ruamel.yaml as yaml

It supports RoundTripLoader which loads the yaml and dumps to file as is.

It also clears the annoying warning of "YAMLLoadWarning: calling yaml.load_all() without Loader=... is deprecated, as the default Loader is unsafe."

Set the RoundTripLoader when loading.

yaml.load_all(open(yaml_file), Loader=yaml.RoundTripLoader)

Set the RoundTripLoader when dumping.

yaml.dump_all(yaml_out.values(), open(yaml_output, 'w'), Dumper=yaml.RoundTripDumper, default_flow_style=False)

cinder/volume/api.py.message:
-1: This doesn't look right.  To me the bug isn't here and it's somewhere else.

It's either in the AvailabilityZoneFilter, that isn't using 'volume_properties' (where we have the volume's availability zone) and itt's using 'resource_properties' instead.

Or it can also be that we need to move the code were we set 'resource_properties' in the the scheduler [1] to an earlier stage on the scheduler request processing

I'm inclined to think it's the latter.

PS: All this would get fixed if we were actually using OVOs instead of dictionaries, since the RequestSpec OVO already has the "resource_properties" property.


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/a323a026f432e5ffb1d34ea52894e8f467f7bbfd/cinder/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L374-L381

The AZFilter is what's looking for it, and it's never been available specifically only for the retype method.   It should be added in the API call, like all the other fields are.  I don't think it's proper to have the scheduler updating/changing the request spec that's coming from the API.

I agree, the OVO stuff should not be covered in this patch to fix this.

But I if our code still looks for that specific location, the more reason to fix it on the scheduler, because we could still be missing other data in 'resource_properties' that is used by other scheduler filters.

For this specific bug we could do
  `'resource_properties': volume,`

But that duplicates data on the RPC transmission, so it would be better to add it on the other end [1]:

    setdefault(request_spec, 'resource_properties', request_spec['volume_properties'])

Although if this is aproblem it should probably be added with a decorator to all the scheduler manager methods that receive a request_spec.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/a323a026f432e5ffb1d34ea52894e8f467f7bbfd/cinder/scheduler/manager.py#L350

In this case "resource_properties" is the old name which was used back when we used filters from oslo incubator, but the same field was renamed to "volume_properties" on the filters when we imported them into our project, so their contents should be the same.  So it looks like we forgot to update the AvailabilityZoneFilter when we imported it [0]. 

In any case, once the scheduler receives the request from the API it is acceptable to massage the data to match its needs.  In this case add a field for backward compatibility.  And this is something we are already doing [1].

You can see how "resource_properties" and "volume_properties" must be the same thing by the treatment we give to the former in our OVO where we throw it away [2] and replace it with a property [3] that returns the "volume_properties".


[0]: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/249255/

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/a323a026f432e5ffb1d34ea52894e8f467f7bbfd/cinder/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py#L374-L381

[2]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/cdfee5608b725e6be35d85f5b04cf51dc756cac5/cinder/objects/request_spec.py#L91

[3]: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/cdfee5608b725e6be35d85f5b04cf51dc756cac5/cinder/objects/request_spec.py#L56-L57

Changing the AZFilter to not use the already existing resource_properties might break things elsewhere.   It's been looking for this specific location forever.   It's just never worked because the resource_properties field was never provided.   This provides what it is already looking for.  Migrating to OVO is a different topic completely, and this fixes the bug.

Code is this:
---
- hosts: localhost
  tasks:

   - name: Set Kubernetes components list
     set_fact:
       kube_component_list:
         - k8s-app=calico-node
         - k8s-app=calico-kube-controllers
         - k8s-app=kube-proxy
         - app=multus
         - app=sriov-cni
         - component=kube-apiserver
         - component=kube-controller-manager
         - component=kube-scheduler

   - name: Update Kubernetes components list

       # We skip the calico-node pod on AIO-DX and STANDARD setups
       # because the pods running on a different host than controller-0 will
       # be unreachable at this moment and the calico-node pods

       kube_component_list: "{{ item }}"

      - "{{ kube_component_list | reject('search', 'calico-node') | list }}"
      - "{{ kube_component_list | reject('search', 'calico-kube-controllers') | list }}"

You are using the id method to get the identity of the current greenthread.Then you are looking up a defaultdict that has a factoryfcuntion setup to return an etcdclient. Now I am not clear as to how this  etcdClient runs in this greenthread? Can you clarify?
Okay. It would help to add this comment to the code.

The aim here is that a given greenthread will only ever use the one etcdclient for its actions - it will never share an etcdclient with any other thread, which is important because they're not threadsafe.  This doesn't make the client do anything, it just makes sure that the client returned is thread-specific.

don't we have some open patches we could reference from https://bugs.launchpad.net/liberasurecode/+bug/1886088 maybe?

Like, I guess maybe they could judge whether they'd like to carry those patches... but the fact that we haven't merged them yet is an indication that we don't entirely trust the approach -- so why should they?

is this only supposed to work with ipv4? 
if it has to support ipv6 the mask should be /128 for ipv6 and /32 for ipv4
In other words, we should just drop the `/32` completely.

I am not sure one can word this without spending a good number of words on it :( But when I look at inventory/group_vars/haproxy/keepalived.yml:57 it looks like the subnet mask is already part of the variable value and it shouldn't be necessary to add it.

These are examples, and we do expect people who're using this to do some thinking and apply some logic. That said, perhaps this could be better commented to prompt the thought. :)

Could you either submit a patch on top of this, or submit a bug to suggest an improvement?

I'm not 100% sure we should be ipwrap'ing an ip address all the time. 

I thought ip wrapping was only needed/used in URI's where the ipv6 ':' is indistinguishable form the port's ':' identifier. I.e RFC 3986 section 3.2.2. 
 https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3986.txt

If it's harmless then I guess it's fine.

As far as I can tell from https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.5/user_guide/playbooks_filters_ipaddr.html the wrapping is harmless, but you do have a point that it's maybe not needed everywhere. I will rebase this change set and work through the changes to make sure they are all necessary.

So I just noticed this call.  Something we want to try and do in this repo is to not import things from neutron if possible.  This call isn't in neutron-lib, but since the class is not required we can just copy the code, or even define a helper locally similar to load_metering_driver() in the neutron tree.  For example:

from neutron_lib.utils import runtime
from oslo_utils import excutils

def load_port_forwarding_plugin():
    """Load port forwarding plugin

    :returns: plugin that is loaded
    :raises ImportError: if fails to load plugin
    """

    try:
        return runtime.load_class_by_alias_or_classname(
                'neutron.service_plugins', 'port_forwarding')
    except ImportError:
        with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception():
            LOG.error("Error loading port_forwarding plugin")

Then call that here.  Sound good?

I did not know we had test for 500 :)

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/contributor/microversions.html

A microversion is needed when the contract to the user is changed. The user contract covers many kinds of information such as:

the Response

* changing a status code on a particular response

* Example: changing the return code of an API from 501 to 400.

Brin, we do not need microversion for this case when any error code (500) is changed to existing returned error code[1]. If newly changed error code is new to that API then we need but 400, 403, 404 and, 415 are universal error code every API return in various sceanrio. 

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/contributor/microversions.html#id2

This is absolutely correct and the docs are clear :
"Fixing a bug so that a 400+ code is returned rather than a 500 or 503 does not require a microversion change."
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#when-do-i-need-a-new-microversion

cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/b.message:
What happens if someone defines qos_policy_group_is_adaptive as '<is> False' in the extra-specs?  It looks like it will be treated as True -- see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741327/4/cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/client/client_base.py@137

Or have you already taken care of that somewhere else?
Here and at line 363, you're just doing a straight get from the extra specs, and if the operator has set this to '<is> True', the comparison to 'True' won't succeed later.
Changed the default value to False, as semantically this param is boolean. Here and elsewhere.

cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/c.message: Now this param arrives here and elsewhere as a boolean True or False.
Refactored the dict key name to remove duplicated code.

cinder/volume/drivers/netapp/dataontap/n.message:
I'm still suspicious about comparing this to the string "True".  As far as I can tell, this is a straight get of the extra_specs, they haven't been processed first.  So I'd expect to see '<is> True' or '<is> False' (or some garbage) here.  How did you test this? An extra spec value can be any string, so if you specifically put 'True' (not '<is> True') as the value for netapp:qos_policy_group_is_adaptive, then when you compare it to 'True' in the code, it will match.  But I think our operators expect to use '<is> True', and that could lead to problems.

(BTW, I wanted to address your question on PS 4 about worrying about '<is> False' -- why would someone bother to set it, when they can have the same effect more easily by leaving it out?  The problem is that if operators are using multiple volume-types, and they want an option "on" in one and "off" in another, they may go ahead and use '<is> False' to make explicit what's being set.)

Thanks for pointing this. Indeed we were testing it the wrong way.

Now the code is properly converting the extra spec to a boolean value.

doc/source/configuration/tables/manual/c.message: This is set using the Block Storage API, so I imagine operators will use '<is> True' or '<is> False' for a boolean.

Oh, makes total sense now. Michael was setting `=True` instead of `=<is> True` (as he wrote in the reno and the commit message). That's why the condition `== "True"` works.

I agree that we should use `<is> True` instead, because operators are used to use this format.

 openstack --os-system-scope all --os-project-name='' token issue

Yeah, we'll have to add it when we finally figure out how to make the cinderclient use tokens, because afaik it cannot use them right now, which means we have no way to use the get_all feature without using curl (which still bother me).

The problem is that the authorization at line 55 is checking two things and we can't tell what the reason for the denial was:

(a) user is not allowed to make this API call, that is, user cannot create/update default_types
(b) user *is* allowed to make the call, but is trying to do it on a project they don't have access to

We wanted to return 404 for situation (b) so you couldn't make a "proper" call on your own project to confirm that you can use the API, and then do (b) with random project ids so that if you get a 403 you know that project exists but if you get a 404 you know that project doesn't exist.

Situation (a) would be a 403 because you're not allowed to make the call at all, so you can't use it to fish for project ids.  The 404 is for situation (b) ... but since we can't tell the difference here, I think we're going to have to go with a 403, or else it will be confusing to operators testing out their policies (they will expect to see a 403 for situation (a))

But it is also late in the day and I may be completely misunderstanding this.  Under what circumstances do you get a ks_exc.http.NotFound?

Well, what it comes down to is that this is why I am skeptical of the move to put all control into the policy config and not have additional internal checks--it's not sensitive to situations like this, where we would like to make a subtle distinction.

So, my thought is that if this is the way the larger community is going, then 403 is fine.  My concern about a 404 is that it's going to make it difficult for an operator to do testing to confirm that the local policy config is rejecting requests that it should because this call will always succeed from an authorization point of view.

But instead of the detailed message you had on PS6, I think just a generic "you are not authorized to perform this action" would be sufficient here.

If cinder reaches this point with a system-scoped context (e.g., the user making the request used a system-scoped token), cinder is going to get an unscoped token since context.project_id is going to evaluate to None and the auth_plugin isn't going to contain the proper scope.

This will work for project administrators, but it might break for system administrators attempting to use the API.


  ERROR cinder.api.middleware.fault keystoneauth1.exceptions.catalog.EmptyCatalog: The service catalog is empty.

Thanks for catching this one!

I think it would be enough to add a parameter to the call, right?

    system_scope=context.system_scope

Following Lance's comment on patch 21, I think we need to add:

    system_scope=context.system_scope

Though I'd like to hear confirmation from him on this.

cinder/volume/volume_types.py.message: (1) there's got to be a better way to do this than iterating through all the default_types.  (2) We may need to introduce filtering on the volume_type_id in the default-types-list call, because if an admin wants to delete a volume type, it can't be done until it's no longer any project's default, and so the admin needs a list of which projects are using that volume_type as a default.  I think you can address both 1 & 2 by introducing a new db api function that takes a volume_type_id and returns a list of projects using it (or maybe by modifying volume_type_default_get).

What exactly is in this list? I think it's models.DefaultVolumeTypes db objects?  You may need to process this and extract the project_ids.

By the way, this is a clever idea to get the operator the list of projects without introducing a new API call.  I guess we could always add it in a new microversion if there's demand.

it's a list of sqlalchemy objects.
Initially i didn't like the idea of looping but it's a waste if we don't.
Will update in next PS.
nit: It would be a bit clearer the intent of this code if it were placed inside the if on L126 (changing that check to check projects_with_default_type instead).
nit: We should use context, like in all the other methods

The reason for setting it like this is because we have 2 context
1st imported from cinder see L#28
2nd is passed to this method (the user context requesting default type or volume create or any other operation)

If we change this to context then it will conflict with L#220 and if we change the import 'as cinder_context' or something then we have to make changes throughout the file
